tier.item: i. * casin-i John-ul kewul-ey pichwue poassta
self-NOM John-ACC mirror re ect
`Himself saw John in the mirror'
On our account, this example is ungrammatical for two reasons. First, the re exiveis unbound yielding a principle
A violation. Additionally, the R-expression John is -marked and hence bound by the sub ject re exive, yielding a
principle C violation. On the accountgiven in the text, scrambling the R-expression past the sub ject will eliminate
only one of these binding violations, namely that of principle A. The R-expression will have been -marked at D-
Structure since it is bound by a sub ject, and hence will continue to be bound at all levels of representation, yielding
the principle C violation. However, such scrambling results in grammaticality as shown in (ii). The slight marginal
status is due only to the awkwardness of this construction.
ii. ? John-uli casin-i ti kewul-ey pichwue poassta
i. * casin-i John-ul kewul-ey pichwue poassta

A violation. Additionally, the R-expression John is -marked and hence bound by the sub ject re exive, yielding a
principle C violation. On the accountgiven in the text, scrambling the R-expression past the sub ject will eliminate
only one of these binding violations, namely that of principle A. The R-expression will have been -marked at D-

the principle C violation. However, such scrambling results in grammaticality as shown in (ii). The slight marginal

ii. ? John-uli casin-i ti kewul-ey pichwue poassta
